qas.question: When are Russian vowels written differently?

answers.text: depending on whether or not the preceding consonant is palatalized

qas.question: What dialect is standard Russian based on?
What language does Russian treat hard consonants similar to?
What is done to unstressed vowels?

answers.text: reduced to near-close vowels or an unclear schwa

qas.question: How many classes are there at the St. Petersburg Phonological School?

plausible_answers.text: depending on whether or not the preceding consonant is palatalized

qas.question: When are Irish vowels written differently?
What pairs do vowels come in, in Irish?
What kind of stress is there in the Irish language?
What is the variation in pitch in Irish?

context: The language possesses five vowels (or <b5_0>six<b5_0/>, under the <a0_0>St. Petersburg Phonological School<a0_0/>), which are written with different letters <a1_0><b6_0>depending on whether or not the preceding consonant is palatalized<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The consonants typically come in <b7_0>plain vs. palatalized pairs<b7_0/>, which are traditionally called hard and soft. (The hard consonants are often velarized, especially before front vowels, as in <a3_0>Irish<a3_0/>). The standard language, based on the <a2_0>Moscow dialect<a2_0/>, possesses <b8_0>heavy<b8_0/> stress and <b9_0>moderate<b9_0/> variation in pitch. Stressed vowels are somewhat lengthened, while unstressed vowels tend to be <a4_0>reduced to near-close vowels or an unclear schwa<a4_0/>. (See also: vowel reduction in Russian.)
